entity.name: Aztec - Coatlicue
entity.subtitle: Coatlicue- "Serpent Skirt" / "She of the Serpent Skirt"
entity.description:
The primordial earth mother goddess, Coatlicue embodies the duality at the heart of Aztec religion.
                Her terrifying appearance - a skirt of writhing serpents, a necklace of human hearts and hands,
                clawed feet, and two serpent heads - represents both the life-giving earth that nurtures crops and
                the devouring grave that reclaims all living things. She is creation and destruction inseparable.

mythology_stories.intro: The most famous myth of Coatlicue describes how she became pregnant while sweeping at Coatepec Hill ("Serpent Mountain"). A ball of hummingbird feathers fell from the sky, and she placed them in her bosom. When she discovered she was pregnant, her four hundred sons (the Centzon Huitznahua, representing the stars of the southern sky) and her daughter Coyolxauhqui (the moon) were outraged.

archetype.name: EARTH MOTHER
archetype.description: Coatlicue embodies the Earth Mother archetype in its fullest form - both nurturing giver of life and devouring grave that reclaims all beings.
